Legal_Issue: Credibility findings, state protection analysis, procedural fairness
Outcome: Judicial review granted, case remanded for redetermination

Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility, availability of state protection, procedural fairness

Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed initially, decision set aside on judicial review

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness in handling post-hearing evidence

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found lacking credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Post-hearing evidence (e.g., tractor registration)

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility issues and procedural non-compliance with evidence submission

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Tractor registration and other post-hearing documents not ruled upon
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness under administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timely application for post-hearing evidence required under Rule 37(1)
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD decision upheld despite procedural breach

Crimes.Legal_Issue: RPD's failure to rule on admissibility of post-hearing documents

Crimes.Application_Factor: Need for formal application to submit evidence after hearing
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged but not proven; document authenticity questioned

Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant faced persecution by OJI officers, who were state agents; lawyer contacted Ombudsman's Office without success; further attempts at state protection would increase danger
Procedural_Issue: RPD unreasonably concluded applicant failed to seek state protection
Evidence_Used: Credible evidence of persecution by state agents
Decision_Outcome: RPD's conclusion was unreasonable
Outcome: Judicial review allowed
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a new RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Presumption of state protection can be rebutted with clear and convincing evidence of state's inability to protect
Decision_Rationale: Persecution was carried out by state agents; requesting further protection attempts would place applicant in greater danger
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (loan agreement, BCR)

Legal_Issue: Can the Defendant rely on sections 366 and 368 of the Criminal Code as part of their defence in a civil patent infringement case?
Governing_Law: Sections 366 and 368 of the Criminal Code
Outcome: The portions of paragraph 22 referring to sections 366 and 368 of the Criminal Code are struck out due to futility and prejudice.
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged false representations or forgery related to a patent application
Key_Factor_in_Determination: No direct connection between the alleged conduct and the Criminal Code provisions; lack of jurisdiction in civil court over criminal matters
Proceeding_Type: Civil patent infringement case with motion to strike
Application_Error: Attempting to invoke criminal statutes in a civil context without statutory authority or direct relevance
Legal_Standard: Federal Court lacks jurisdiction over criminal prosecutions unless explicitly authorized
Application_Factor: Relevance of criminal law provisions to civil defence
Decision_Outcome: Motion partially granted: references to Criminal Code struck out, s. 76 Patent Act may remain
Document_Fraud: Allegation of forged document related to patent application

Legal_Issue: Can the Defendant rely on penal provisions of the Patent Act and Criminal Code as part of their defence in a civil patent infringement case?
Outcome: Portion of paragraph 22 referring to the Criminal Code is struck out as scandalous and prejudicial.
Basis_of_Claim: Defendant alleged Plaintiffs engaged in misconduct under penal statutes including forgery
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of direct connection between penal allegations and civil harm; no general criminal jurisdiction in Federal Court
Proceeding_Type: Civil patent infringement with motion to strike
Application_Error: Use of criminal law provisions where no cause of action or defence arises from them
Legal_Standard: Federal Court cannot entertain criminal charges absent statutory grant
Application_Factor: Applicability of penal provisions in civil litigation
Decision_Outcome: References to Criminal Code struck out; amendment allowed regarding s. 76 of Patent Act
Document_Fraud: Allegation of forged documents in patent context

Legal_Issue: Can the Defendant use s. 76 of the Patent Act and ss. 366 and 368 of the Criminal Code as a defense or counterclaim in a civil patent infringement case?
Governing_Law: Sections 366 and 368 of the Criminal Code
Procedural_Stage: Motion to strike parts of Defence and Counterclaim
Decision_Outcome: References to Criminal Code removed; liberty granted to amend concerning s. 76 of Patent Act
Legal_Rule: s. 76 prohibits false representations about patent status; ss. 366–368 are criminal forgery provisions not applicable in civil defences
Grounds_for_Claim: Plaintiffs allegedly made false representations about a patent application
Outcome_on_Merits: No valid defence based on Criminal Code; s. 76 may have arguable relevance
Legal_Framework: Civil patent law framework with limited applicability of penal provisions
Defendant_Response: Invoked s. 76 Patent Act and Criminal Code provisions as part of defence
Remedy_Requested: Striking out of irrelevant and prejudicial allegations
Outcome: Partial success for Plaintiffs: Criminal Code references struck, s. 76 issue preserved subject to amendment

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to disclose prior refusals and procedural fairness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, case returned for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant provided explanations later; officer did not adequately assess

Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA and IRPR - requirement to declare prior refusals
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Omission on application corrected later
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of adequate response to applicant's explanation by officer
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to initially declare prior refusal
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Procedural fairness and truthfulness in application
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicant’s subsequent correction and explanation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty of procedural fairness under administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Prior visa refusals
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision due to procedural unfairness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No explicit fraud found, but omission initially made

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act - duration of stay

Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to consider detailed explanation for overstay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Assessment of intent and ties to home country
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Explanation letters, evidence of ties to Japan
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer misinterpreted facts about ties to Japan
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant provided credible reasons for overstay
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable and set aside

Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to engage with explanation and applied incorrect reasoning

Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to declare prior refusal, lack of new contract

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Valid Labour Market Opinion, explanation for overstay
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness and procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Intent to leave Canada, job offer validity
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision due to flawed reasoning
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No document forgery, but concerns about completeness of disclosure

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim credibility and identity verification
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in finding Elhassan failed to establish identity and lacked credibility

Legal_Issue: Does the applicant meet the tripartite test for a stay of removal?
Outcome: The applicant does not meet the criteria for a stay of removal; the motion is dismissed.
Credibility_Assessment: The applicant failed to prove unusual hardship or personalized risk in Ukraine. Claims were assessed multiple times, finding no significant risk.
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to establish irreparable harm and serious question to be tried; balance of convenience did not favor applicant.
Proceeding_Type: Federal Court application for stay of removal
Assessment_Standard: Tripartite test: (a) serious question to be tried, (b) irreparable harm if injunction not granted, (c) balance of convenience favors applicant.
Legal_Standard: Tripartite test for stay of removal
Application_Factor: Unsuccessful prior immigration applications, repeated assessments of risk, lack of evidence of persecution or hardship
Decision_Outcome: Application for stay of removal dismissed

Crime_Name: Administrative Error in Visa Application Process
Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer correctly applied s. 78(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations in assessing Mr. Marr's educational credentials
Governing_Law: Section 78(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Outcome: The officer erred by failing to consider special circumstances under s. 78(4); decision set aside and application remitted for reconsideration
Evidence_Type: Educational credential, duration of study, information on Scotland’s education system
Legal_Provision: s. 78(4), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient points awarded due to misapplication of regulations regarding educational credentials
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer failed to consider special circumstances such as shorter education system in Scotland
Decision_Maker: Visa officer, later reviewed by Federal Court
Application_Error: Incorrect point allocation (15 instead of 20) for educational credential
Evidence_Ignored: Potential relevance of Scotland’s shorter post-secondary education system
Application_Factor: Two-year post-secondary credential with 13 years of study (not meeting 14-year threshold)
Decision_Outcome: Application refused initially; decision quashed and remitted for re-evaluation

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Board's decision, credibility concerns, risk of persecution
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in testimony regarding travel details and church practices, limited knowledge of Pentecostal beliefs
Evidence_Type: Testimony, documentary evidence on conditions in Fujian province, church membership claims
Legal_Provision: Section 97 and 98 of IRPA, standard of reasonableness
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged religious persecution in China due to Pentecostal church involvement
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility of applicant, plausibility of church membership, country condition evidence
Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court
Application_Error: Inconsistent statements, lack of corroborating evidence for church involvement
Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness in administrative law review
Application_Factor: Plausibility of claim, consistency of testimony, knowledge of religious practices
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision upheld, refugee claim dismissed
Document_Fraud: No explicit finding, but inconsistencies in supporting claims

Legal_Issue: Whether the absence of use of the trademark CFP by IBCFP in Canada can be excused due to special circumstances
Evidence_Assessment: New evidence showing continuous use by the College and special circumstances
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed; absence of use excused due to special circumstances
Burden_of_Proof: IBCFP to demonstrate special circumstances excusing non-use
Credibility_Factor: Inadvertent failure to appoint the College as a registered user
Legal_Rule: Section 44(3) allows expungement unless special circumstances excuse non-use
Key_Evidence_Considered: Continuous use by the College, intent to maintain use, inadvertent administrative omission
Defendant_Response: Argued special circumstances due to inadvertent failure to appoint College as registered user
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, intent evidence, usage records
Outcome: Appeal allowed; trademark not expunged

Crimes.Crime_Name: Being a member of a terrorist group
Nature_of_Acts: Worked for the LTTE under duress
Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection under Article 1F(b)
Consequences_of_Action: Excluded from refugee protection; decision set aside and remitted for reconsideration

Crimes.Crime_Name: Providing or making available property or financial or other related services knowing that they will be used for the purpose of benefiting any person who is facilitating or carrying out terrorist activity
Nature_of_Acts: Provided services to LTTE under threat
Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection under Article 1F(b)
Consequences_of_Action: Excluded from refugee protection; decision found unreasonable and remitted for reconsideration

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of internal flight alternative (IFA) given daughter's medical needs
Evidence_Assessment: Barriers to accessing cancer treatment in Mumbai for the applicant's daughter
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court found IFA determination unreasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate risk, but officer must reasonably assess IFA
Credibility_Factor: Medical evidence regarding daughter’s health and treatment requirements
Legal_Rule: IFA test: (1) no serious possibility of persecution; (2) conditions not unreasonable to seek refuge internally
Grounds_for_Claim: Specialized medical needs make Mumbai an unreasonable IFA
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical reports on daughter’s cancer treatment needs, healthcare access in Mumbai
Legal_Framework: PRRA process, s. 97 and s. 112 of IRPA, case law on IFA
Defendant_Response: Officer asserted Mumbai was a viable IFA
Evidence_Type: Documentary medical evidence, country condition information
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision remitted to a different officer

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present in Canada for 571 days out of the required 1,095 days within four years before application; extensive absences from Canada
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet minimum physical presence requirement; centralized mode of living test applied but not satisfied
Procedural_Issue: Appeal filed under Federal Courts Act and Citizenship Act; review by Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Family ties, property ownership, duration and frequency of absences
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient physical presence in Canada; lack of compelling evidence to establish a centralized mode of living in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Outcome: Citizenship application denied
Legal_Standard_Applied: Re Koo test (centralized mode of living test)
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge reasonably concluded that the Applicant did not meet the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c); no legal or factual errors identified

Legal_Issue: Failure to distinguish between humanitarian and compassionate considerations and pre-removal risk assessments
Evidence_Assessment: Risk factors relevant to humanitarian and compassionate grounds were not properly considered
Decision_Outcome: Error in law found
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Credibility_Factor: Perceived lack of risk upon return to Hungary
Legal_Rule: Section 25 IRPA for humanitarian and compassionate considerations; Sections 97, 112, 113 for pre-removal risk assessments
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on legal interpretation
Grounds_for_Claim: Conflation of H&C considerations with risk assessment, closed mind to relevant factors
Key_Evidence_Considered: Family circumstances, country conditions in Hungary, individual risk factors
Defendant_Response: Immigration officer did not differentiate assessment types
Evidence_Type: Narrative submissions, country reports, personal affidavits
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision and remittal for proper assessment
Outcome: Application granted, case remanded for re-evaluation under section 25 IRPA

Application_Facts: Appellant was physically present in Canada for only 232 days over a four-year period; maintained a home in Canada; paid taxes as a resident; promoted Canadian interests in Hong Kong; absences were due to business responsibilities in Hong Kong
Residency_Compliance: No, did not accumulate at least three years of residence in Canada within four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal involved a trial de novo before the Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Physical presence records, ownership/maintenance of home in Canada, tax filings, promotion of Canadian interests, nature and purpose of absences
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient demonstration that connection to Canada was more substantial than to Hong Kong
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Outcome: Citizenship application denied
Legal_Standard_Applied: Residence under Section 5(1)(c) requires both physical presence and intent to reside, with stronger ties to Canada than to another country
Decision_Rationale: Appellant's absences were not temporary; business responsibilities in Hong Kong outweighed his connections to Canada; residence requirement not satisfied despite some ties to Canada

Crime_Name: Risk of Persecution or Harm upon Removal
Violation_Type: Failure to assess personalized risk as required by law
Application_Facts: Applicant is a Tamil individual facing potential removal to Sri Lanka; Minister's Delegate concluded risk was generalized, not personalized
Procedural_Issue: Re-assessment process may have failed to properly apply the balance of probabilities test; risk of irreparable harm if removed prior to judicial review
Evidence_Used: Evidence indicating Tamils face unique dangers in Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Minister's Delegate dismissed specific risks to Tamils as generalized without sufficient justification
Decision_Outcome: Minister's Delegate found no more than generalized risk
Outcome: Stay of removal granted by the court
Relief_Sought: Stay of removal pending judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Prevention of removal until resolution of judicial review
Decision_Rationale: Serious questions exist about the re-assessment; removal would render judicial review ineffective, constituting irreparable harm

Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in finding that state protection was available to the applicant?
Governing_Law: The Board must determine if state protection is adequate and effective, considering evidence of similarly situated individuals and cultural attitudes.
Outcome: The Board erred by ignoring relevant evidence and failing to assess state protection adequately. Judicial review allowed case remanded for redetermination.
Evidence_Type: Evidence of a similar case where police ignored a gay man's plea for help
Basis_of_Claim: Applicant feared persecution in St. Vincent due to perceived homosexuality
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Evidence of similarly situated individuals not receiving protection
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of the Refugee Protection Division’s decision
Application_Error: Board dismissed relevant evidence without addressing its relevance
Evidence_Ignored: Case of a gay man whose plea for police help was ignored
Legal_Standard: State protection must be adequate and effective
Application_Factor: Perceived homosexuality as grounds for persecution
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review; decision set aside and remanded

Risk_Assessment: Risk of persecution due to sexual orientation
Risk_Nature: Non-state actor persecution with lack of state protection
Threat_Source: Societal actors due to anti-LGBTQ+ attitudes
Evidence_Sufficiency: Evidence provided on Michael, a similarly situated individual
Evidence_Type: Testimony and documentary evidence of lack of police protection

Risk_Assessment: Risk of persecution due to sexual orientation
Risk_Nature: Non-state actor persecution with lack of state protection
Threat_Source: Societal actors due to anti-LGBTQ+ attitudes
Evidence_Sufficiency: Evidence provided on Michael, a similarly situated individual
Evidence_Type: Testimony and documentary evidence of lack of police protection

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Provide Necessities of Life
Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in finding that state protection was available to the applicant?
Governing_Law: Under IRPA, a person is a Convention refugee if they have a well-founded fear of persecution and cannot avail themselves of state protection.
Evidence_Assessment: Board failed to assess evidence of similarly situated individuals
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remitted for redetermination
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show lack of state protection
Legal_Rule: State protection must be reasonably forthcoming and effective
Key_Evidence_Considered: Case of Michael who was not protected by police
Outcome: Court allowed judicial review and referred matter back to Board
Legal_Provision: IRPA Section related to Convention refugees

Application_Facts: Applicant convicted of fraud, deemed criminally inadmissible, permanent residence denied, refugee claim referred for hearing
Procedural_Issue: Request for interim prohibition order to delay refugee hearing
Evidence_Used: Conviction record, refugee claim documentation
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Speculative claims of harm if deported
Credibility_Assessment: Fear of harm in Ghana deemed speculative
Decision_Outcome: Interim order dismissed
Outcome: Refugee hearing allowed to proceed
Relief_Sought: Prevent refugee claim hearing during permanent residence processing
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Rationale: No irreparable harm proven; balance of convenience did not favor applicant

Application_Facts: The Minister did not provide evidence that the June 29, 2009 letter was sent to the applicant's representative; tribunal record and delivery notification were deemed insufficient.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to prove communication was sent to applicant's representative
Evidence_Used: Tribunal record
Delivery Status Notification
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of affidavit evidence from the Minister confirming dispatch of communication
Decision_Outcome: Refusal of application quashed
Outcome: Case remanded for redetermination by the Minister with all materials considered
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of refusal and reconsideration of application
Legal_Standard_Applied: Minister bears risk of failed communication without proof of transmission
Decision_Rationale: Absence of proper evidentiary proof (e.g., affidavit) that communication was sent renders the refusal invalid

Violation_Type: Refusal of protection based on risk assessment
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) - Protection obligations
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk of persecution in Turkey due to Kurdish ethnicity and political activities; PRRA officer assessed new evidence including a lawyer's letter and country reports
Claimant_Status: Protected Person or Applicant for Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA)
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged inconsistency in applicant's evidence regarding arrests and involvement
Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer may have unreasonably dismissed key evidence (lawyer's letter on 1998 arrest)
Evidence_Used: Lawyer's letter confirming 1998 arrest, UK country report on treatment of activist Kurds, applicant's statements on political involvement
Evidentiary_Deficiency: PRRA officer found applicant's evidence unpersuasive; lack of corroboration on arrest claims
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility questioned regarding past arrests and level of political activism
Decision_Outcome: PRRA application denied
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; decision upheld despite error on one factual finding
Relief_Sought: Protection under PRRA due to risk of persecution, torture, or cruel and unusual treatment
Remedy_Sought: Quashing of PRRA decision and referral back for re-determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether the PRRA officer's decision was reasonable under the standard of reasonableness
Decision_Rationale: Even if the finding on the 1998 arrest was unreasonable, the overall conclusion stands as arrests alone do not constitute persecution; country evidence indicates harassment but not systematic persecution

Decision_Outcome: May 5, 1992 decision quashed, effects stayed pending new tribunal
Burden_of_Proof: On appellant to demonstrate procedural unfairness
Legal_Rule: Administrative decisions must adhere to procedural fairness standards, including unbiased tribunal, proper notice, and right to representation
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on context
Grounds_for_Claim: Bias, lack of proper notice, denial of right to representation
Outcome_on_Merits: Procedural unfairness found; decision set aside
Key_Evidence_Considered: Tribunal proceedings, notice documentation, participation records
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision, redetermination by new tribunal
Outcome: Decision quashed, stay of effect, new tribunal ordered
Authority: Cowessess Indian Band #73 Appeal Tribunal, judicial review court

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant faced persecution due to domestic violence and threats from her ex-husband, a police officer, in Mexico
Procedural_Issue: Overlooked key evidence regarding ineffective implementation of laws in Guanajuato
Evidence_Used: Evidence of domestic violence, threats from ex-husband, legal protections in Mexico, lack of effective state protection in Guanajuato
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient consideration of evidence on lack of state protection
Credibility_Assessment: Board's credibility reasoning impacted by failure to consider key evidence
Decision_Outcome: Board denied refugee status
Outcome: Application for judicial review granted
Remedy_Sought: Remand for reconsideration by a new Board panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Persecution or danger in home country with inability to rely on state protection
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision was unreasonable due to inadequate assessment of state protection and overlooked evidence

Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate Grounds Application Rejection
Application_Facts: Lack of substantive evidence regarding hardship or unique circumstances; consideration of children's interests in Canada and Nigeria
Evidence_Used: Assessment of hardship, establishment, and risk factors
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of substantive evidence on hardship or unique circumstances
Decision_Outcome: H&C application rejected
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; decision upheld
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the children as a factor in H&C assessment
Decision_Rationale: No compelling reasons to grant an exception; children's interests considered but not outweighing other factors

Legal_Issue: Whether Sanofi is liable to Apotex for losses due to delayed market entry of generic ramipril under Section 8 of the PM (NOC) Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies on market dynamics, pricing, and regulatory impacts
Decision_Outcome: Sanofi is liable to compensate Apotex for lost profits during the Relevant Period
Burden_of_Proof: On Apotex to demonstrate entitlement to damages under Section 8
Credibility_Factor: Court relied on expert evidence to construct hypothetical market scenario
Legal_Rule: Section 8 allows second person to claim damages if prohibition application by first person fails and causes market delay
Standard_of_Review: Objective assessment of market conditions and damages based on evidentiary record
Grounds_for_Claim: Delayed market entry of Apotex's generic ramipril due to Sanofi's unsuccessful prohibition application
Outcome_on_Merits: Apotex succeeded on the merits; Sanofi found liable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Market share projections, timing of market entries by authorized generics, trade spend, API costs
Defendant_Response: Sanofi contested liability and damages, but court found in favor of Apotex
Evidence_Type: Expert testimony, regulatory timelines, market data
Remedy_Requested: Damages for lost profits due to delayed market entry
Outcome: Court ordered Sanofi to calculate and pay damages to Apotex as per court's guidelines

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed his visitor visa and failed to attend initial proceedings; later attended with counsel.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of notice and denial of interpreter rights
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer to issue exclusion order
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Proof of visa overstay, attendance records, representation by counsel, language comprehension
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None found – applicant understood English and was represented
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of lack of notice not supported by evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Cancellation of removal order and procedural reconsideration
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No breach of procedural fairness; mandatory exclusion order under Regulation 228 due to overstay

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, missed initial proceedings, later attended with counsel; claimed lack of notice, interpreter issues, and ignored H&C factors.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Claims of inadequate notice, lack of interpreter, and failure to consider H&C
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of immigration officer’s duty in procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of non-attendance, counsel representation, demonstrated English comprehension, absence of H&C referral requirement
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: H&C claims not substantiated or required at exclusion stage
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant understood proceedings; interpreter not necessary
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn exclusion order based on procedural unfairness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandatory exclusion for inadmissibility under subsection 29(2)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No obligation to provide interpreter when comprehension evident; H&C considerations separate from exclusion orders

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligation under section 28
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: section 28 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visitor visa and did not fulfill residency obligations; submitted H&C application but excluded from IAD referral
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – failed to meet residency obligation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to consider humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) factors
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority to issue exclusion without IAD referral when inadmissible solely for overstay
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa duration records, departure history, submission of H&C application
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: H&C factors not grounds to bypass mandatory exclusion under section 28
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No challenge to credibility; focus on legal applicability
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Exclusion order issued lawfully without IAD referral
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Set aside exclusion order and refer to IAD
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Procedural referral to Immigration Appeal Division
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandatory exclusion under IRPA when inadmissible solely for overstay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 28 requires exclusion order without IAD referral if inadmissibility is based solely on overstay

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 551 days over four years, retained business interests in Colombia, and traveled frequently.
Procedural_Issue: Appeal under s. 14(5) of Citizenship Act and s. 21 of Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Used: Physical presence records, business ties in Colombia, travel history, Koo factors assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship judge found stronger connection to Colombia
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied
Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralization of mode of existence, Koo factors
Decision_Rationale: Frequent absences and significant ties to Colombia indicated that the applicant had not centralized their life in Canada.

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 117(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada on a temporary visa and remained beyond the authorized period before applying for refugee protection.
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of IRB decisions
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony regarding fear of spousal abuse
Documentary evidence on country conditions in Jamaica
Record of visa entry and expiry dates
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to consider key evidence supporting subjective fear and state protection gaps
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found lack of subjective and objective fear; court found assessment patently unreasonable
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Re-determination by a new panel of the IRB
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under Article 1A(2) of the Refugee Convention
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness simpliciter for state protection analysis
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board inadequately analyzed applicant’s fear and Jamaica’s capacity to protect victims of domestic violence
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 114(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: After refugee claim was denied, applicant remained in Canada despite being subject to a removal order.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant under removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging basis of original refugee determination affecting removal liability
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court authority to review IRB decisions impacting enforceability of removal orders
Evidence_Used: Testimony about threats from ex-partner
Country condition reports on domestic violence in Jamaica
IRB decision record and removal order documentation
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board overlooked credible evidence of risk and misinterpreted state protection availability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned applicant’s credibility; court found this assessment unreasonable
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee protection denied, removal order issued
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case referred back for re-determination
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal and refugee status recognition
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Re-hearing before a different IRB panel
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Risk of persecution or cruel and unusual treatment due to domestic violence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient analysis of Jamaica’s ability to protect women facing domestic abuse; errors in evidence interpretation
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)
